talk.start.para: asked the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 4 February 2003:

question.para: (1) How many telephone calls have been received by the 1800 123 400 hotline for the “Lets look out for Australia” terrorism alert campaign.
(2) What is the general nature of calls believed to be genuine.
(3) How many calls have been found to be hoax calls.
(4) How many calls have been acted upon and by whom.
(5) What action has been taken by the various authorities in response to those calls believed to be genuine.
(6) Is the Government satisfied with the public response to its terrorism alert campaign; if so, why; if not, why not.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) As at 28 February 2003, the National Security Hotline had taken 11,527 calls.

(2) The majority of calls are genuine. These calls involved the provision of information about suspicious activity, the seeking of information about security arrangements and the threat environment, and comments regarding the campaign.

(3) There have been three persons charged (one found guilty) for making a hoax or malicious call to the National Security Hotline. One related to an alleged bomb threat in Western Australia (found guilty), one related to an alleged threat, in New South Wales, against the Prime Minister and another related to an alleged extortion attempt in Victoria.

(4) Commonwealth, State or Territory agencies analyse information received. All information relating to suspicious activities is forwarded to them by the Hotline for assessment. It is a matter for those agencies to determine the response to each call.
(5) Agencies have advised that they are receiving useful information from the Hotline. Action taken is dependent on the nature of the information.

(6) The fact that in excess of 11,500 calls have been received by the National Security Hotline since its inception is an indication of the success of the campaign. The majority of calls received by the Hotline relate to members of the public reporting, what is to them, suspicious activity. If only one of the calls prevents a terrorist attack, then the campaign will have served its purpose.

talk.start.para: asked the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 4 February 2003:

question.para: (1) Further to his reply to question No. 1129, why did he believe that it was improbable that Dr Malcolm Arthur Colston would give his consent to exercise an exemption under the Privacy Act which would release the medical reports of the two eminent and independent medical specialists who examined Dr Colston in May 1999 in relation to his fitness to stand trial on twenty-eight charges of defrauding the Commonwealth through travel rorts.
(2) Has he asked Dr Colston for his consent to the release of those two medical reports; if so when and what was Dr Colston's reply; if not, why not.

(3) Is he able to say whether the provisions of the Privacy Act to which he refers constitute a compellable power at law on him to exercise that power; if so, upon what basis is that compellable-duty based; if not, why is the statutory power under the Privacy Act to seek the exemption from Dr Colston to consent to the disclosure of the subject information a non-compellable duty.
(4) Is the exercise of this power an administrative power held in the hands of himself; if not, what type of power is it.

(5) What power does he rely upon to make a decision on a balance of probabilities to refuse to consider the exercise of the statutory power under the Privacy Act to seek the consent of Dr Colston to publicly release the two medical reports.
(6) Does the discretionary power to seek the consent of Dr Colston rest with Dr Colston.
(7) Will he exercise his power afforded under the Privacy Act; if so, when; if not, why not.

(8) In his refusal to exercise his statutory power to seek the consent of Dr Colston to the release of the two medical reports is he able to say whether this could be a breach of power or an error of law; if so, how; if not, why not.

(9) What are the reasons that he believes that the public interest of twenty-eight charges of defrauding the Commonwealth through travel rorts is outweighed by the privacy provisions protecting the disclosure of the two medical reports in relation to Dr Colston.

(10) In forming his opinion in relation to the weight of balance between the two competing interests, has he exercised an administrative power or a judicial power in his decision not to release the subject information covered by parliamentary privilege; if so, what is that power; if not, why not.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) to (7) As explained in the answer given in response to Question on Notice No. 1129, Information Privacy Principle 11 of the Privacy Act provides that, subject to certain exceptions, personal information should not be publicly disclosed. One of the exceptions is where the subject of the information has consented to disclosure. Under the Privacy Act, consent is simply a qualification to a prohibition on disclosure and the Act neither imposes a duty nor confers a power on me to seek Dr Colston's consent.

In this case I will not seek consent because it is improbable that Dr Colston would consent to publication. The medical reports contain very sensitive and personal health information and in general individuals do not consent to publication of personal information of that kind. In addition, as a general rule seeking consent is inappropriate if it might be misinterpreted by the subject of the information or others as indicating a belief on my part that there may be sufficient public interest in disclosure for me to consider making an exception to the Privacy Act general principle of non disclosure of personal information. As explained in the answer given in response to Question on Notice No. 1129, in my view the balance of the public interest in this case does not weigh in favour of public release of the reports.
(8) It is not appropriate for me to give legal advice in answer to questions on notice.

(9) In giving the answer given in response to Question on Notice No. 1129 that the balance of the public interest does not weigh in favour of public release of the reports, I balanced the relative weight of the competing public interests. Given that disclosure of the reports is not necessary to protect the public revenue or to enforce the law (as stated in response to Question on Notice No. 1573 of 29 May 2000), the public interest in the public having access to the information is not strong. On the other hand the public interest against disclosure is strong, as evidenced by the Privacy Act general principle of non disclosure of personal information and the fact that in general individuals do not consent to publication of personal health information.
(10) It is not appropriate for me to give legal advice in answer to questions on notice.

talk.start.para: asked the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 4 February 2003:

question.para: Further to paragraph 3 of his reply to question No. 1130 that the public interest is not established because something is of interest to the public but a higher standard of serious concern or benefit to the public is required rather than merely of individual interest, why is the matter of the public release of those two medical reports, bearing in mind their relationship to the twenty-eight charges of defrauding the Commonwealth through travel rorts originally brought against Dr Malcolm Arthur Colston, something that is of insufficient concern or benefit to the public.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: As explained in the answer given in response to Question on Notice No. 1130, in arriving at a balance of public interest in a particular case, it is necessary to consider whether the public interest considerations in disclosing the information outweigh the public interest in government agencies protecting the privacy of sensitive personal information in their possession. In this instance the balance favours a decision to refuse public release of the reports. The reasons for that view are outlined in my answer to Question on Notice No. 1336.

talk.start.para: asked the Acting Minister for Transport and Regional Services, upon notice, on 4 February 2003:

talk.start.para: asked the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 4 February 2003:

question.para: (1) Has he sought advice in respect to the differential superannuation entitlements of employees working beyond the age of 70.
(2) Will the Government take legislative or other measures to address the apparently discriminatory treatment of employees after they reach the age of 70.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) On 9 January 2003, the Government released an Information Paper setting out in detail its proposals for age discrimination legislation. The proposals include exemptions for legitimate age criteria in the provision of superannuation.

The superannuation exemptions proposed for the age discrimination legislation were developed in the course of extensive consultations with business and community organisations. There was broad agreement in consultations that issues arising from the age criteria in the Commonwealth superannuation regime were best addressed through the ongoing review and adaptation of the superannuation system, rather than through age discrimination legislation.

State and Territory anti-discrimination laws provide exemptions for superannuation, which allow for the inherently age-based nature of the existing superannuation system. Commonwealth anti-discrimination laws, such as the Sex Discrimination Act 1984 and the Disability Discrimination Act 1992, also provide exemptions for superannuation.

Age-related criteria are central to the Government's policies to promote better incomes in retirement through superannuation and the age pension, and to ensure that superannuation (which is concessionally taxed) is appropriately used for retirement purposes. Superannuation and related social security and taxation laws are finely balanced and constantly monitored. The Government continues to monitor the operation of the superannuation system to ensure that it meets the needs of an ageing population.

(2) The contribution and compulsory cashing rules for superannuation are designed to reduce the risk that concessionally taxed benefits are used for estate planning and not genuine retirement income purposes. Within this framework, however, the Government is committed to ensuring that the superannuation system reflects the needs of the ageing Australian population.

On 1 July 2002, the Government implemented its 2001 election commitment to raise the maximum age limit for personal superannuation contributions from age 70 to 75. All superannuation fund members aged between 65 and 75 can now make personal contributions to superannuation if they are working at least 10 hours per week.

As a consequence of this measure, the Government has also changed the compulsory cashing rules for those aged between 70 and 75. The benefits of these members must be compulsorily cashed if the member is working fewer than 10 hours per week. Previously, all members aged over 70 were required to work full-time (at least 30 hours per week) to avoid compulsory cashing. The 30-hour standard remains for people aged over 75.

The above data indicates TPV holders' nationality, rather than the country of origin as requested. Data held by my Department in relation to nationality is more reliable than country of origin. The Refugees Convention requires consideration of claims against the country of nationality or, if the asylum seeker is stateless, their country of habitual residence. An applicant's country of origin is not a relevant consideration when assessing a protection visa application, and is often not indicative of a person's nationality or country of habitual residence.

(3) (a)-(c) Figures for the location of TPV holders in Australia at any given time are not currently available in the form requested. In general, lawful temporary residents of Australia are not obliged to keep DIMIA informed of their whereabouts unless they are applying for a further visa. However, statutory requirements that TPV holders keep my Department informed of their address were introduced in September 2001.

There is a significant number of TPVs granted prior to the introduction of this requirement and some 16% of all TPV holders have not lodged further visa applications. Where TPV holders have made further applications for a protection visa, they are obliged as visa applicants, to keep DIMIA informed of their current address. Anecdotal information indicates that many of these addresses are not assiduously updated by the applicant until their TPV approaches the 30 month point, at which stage applicants are expecting that active decision making on their further PV application might commence.

The programme is also promoted through the Commonwealth Regional Information Service.
(b) Where DOTARS advertises in print media such as local and national newspapers, the advertisements are paid for.
(3) (a) Newcastle Structural Adjustment Programme

In 1997 the Prime Minister established the Newcastle Structural Adjustment Fund (NSAF) following the announcement of the closure of the BHP Steel Division. To assist the local economy to adjust to the job losses, the Federal Government allocated $10 million for initiatives that would generate sustainable private sector employment growth within the Hunter Region.
These grants are offered as a means to:
- promote innovative worthwhile research into road safety; and

- broaden the base of effective road safety researchers by encouraging established scientists, recent postgraduates, and commercial and community-based organisations to undertake research in the road safety field.

Applications are invited from Australasian academic research institutions and Australasian commercial or community-based organisations. The research can be into any aspect of road safety. The maximum duration of a project is twelve months, and the maximum grant available is $25,000.

The Regional Assistance Programme generates employment in metropolitan, regional and remote Australia by encouraging local community action to boost business growth and create sustainable jobs. It provides seed funding for innovative, quality projects of value to the community.

Dairy RAP is designed to assist communities that have been impacted upon by the deregulation of the dairy industry. The programme facilitates long-term employment by supplementing business investment and provides support for services that will lead to on-going economic and social benefits for regions affected by dairy deregulation.

Regional Solutions Programme is aimed at helping regional, rural and remote communities to build their capacity and to identify and implement development opportunities. It helps communities to move beyond planning by providing assistance to implement community initiatives, including community infrastructure.
(b) Newcastle Structural Adjustment Programme
The Minister for Regional Services, Territories and Local Government allocates funds.

Applications are assessed by an expert panel drawn from the Australian Transport Safety Bureau. Where appropriate, the selection committee seeks input from experts in other areas of the Department or from experts in the particular field of research to which the application relates.
Final decisions on all applications are made by the Assistant Secretary, Stronger Regions Branch, Department of Transport and Regional Services.
The Department of Transport and Regional Services is responsible for the allocation of funds.
Final decisions on all applications are made by the Minister for Regional Services, Territories and Local Government.

No, veterans residing in aged care facilities, funded by the Department of Health and Ageing, are not eligible to receive Veterans' Home Care services. This accommodation is already receiving government funding under the Aged Care Act 1997, which is set at a level to meet residents' needs.

Access to the provision of equipment under the RAP to entitled persons is based upon an assessed clinical need(s) and is governed by the Treatment Principles, prepared under Section 90 of the Veterans' Entitlements Act 1986. The assessment of an entitled person's clinical need/s is conducted by specified health professionals, usually an occupational therapist, upon referral from, and in consultation with, the entitled person's Local Medical Officer (LMO).
The guidelines governing the supply of RAP items to entitled persons residing in institutions (including low level hostels) is specified under Treatment Principle 11.3.6.

In genral, it is the responsibility of the Residential Aged Care Facility (RACF) to cater for the needs of its residents. However, if the Repatriation Commission considers the equipment requested by the entitled person receiving low-level care or high level care is not the responsibility of the RACF because of any legislation, charges or subsidies, then the Commission may consider the request based on assessed clinical need and in accordance with the national guidelines. These guidelines apply regardless of whether the person making the request is in an institution or not and relate to the item requested.

answer.para: (1) The Commissioner of Taxation issued a Taxpayer Alert on 11 February 2003 to provide an early warning to taxpayers of the issues arising from a scheme that uses an interposed fixed trust to distribute profits into a self managed superannuation fund.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Health and Ageing, upon notice, on 13 February 2003:

question.para: (1) Further to part (5) of the answer to question No. 358 (Hansard, 19 August 2002, page 4941) and part (7) of the answer to question No. 884 (Hansard, 22 October 2002, page 8391), has the Minister seen a News Release by the NSW Minister for Health on 11 February 2003, titled “MRI at Concord Hospital” advising that the Carr Labor Government has already promised to fund the significant building works required and the ongoing operating costs for a new Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI) unit at Concord Repatriation General Hospital, but that the NSW Minister first needs the licence from the Federal Government.
(2) When will the Minister offer Concord Repatriation General Hospital an MRI licence and allow it to provide Medicare eligible MRI services.

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Health and Ageing has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

answer.para: (1) I have not seen the news release by the NSW Minister for Health titled “MRI at Concord Hospital”. Staff in my Department have searched extensively for this news release and have not been able to locate it. In fact, staff at the NSW Health Minister's own office are unaware of it.

With regard to the NSW Health Minister's need for a federal licence, whilst the Commonwealth Government regulates the conditions under which MRI services attract Medicare rebates it does not regulate or restrict the establishment of MRI units in public hospitals. As such, there is no impediment to the New South Wales State Government funding the establishment of a MRI unit at the Concord Repatriation General Hospital. I would welcome the New South Wales Government's commitment to the provision of quality health care were it to do so.

(2) The Government has not made any decisions on future growth for MRI and I am therefore unable to indicate whether Concord Hospital would obtain Medicare eligibility for a MRI unit. In addition, the Department of Health and Ageing is currently negotiating with the Diagnostic Imaging (DI) profession on future DI agreements. Future priorities for MRI and other DI services will need to be considered in the context of these negotiations. It is also worth noting that Medicare funded access to MRI in metropolitan Sydney is above the national average.

talk.start.para: asked the Acting Minister for Transport and Regional Services, upon notice, on 13 February 2003:

question.para: Has a review been undertaken of the Navigation Act; if so, (a) who conducted the review, (b) was a report produced, (c) when will it be available to the public, (d) what did the review recommend, (e) what is the status of the recommendations, (f) when will the industry be consulted and (g) when will they be implemented.

talker.name: Tuckey, Wilson, MP
Mr Tuckey
talker.role: Minister for Regional Services, Territories and Local Government

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: The Government decided on 16 December 1997 to review the Act in two stages. The first stage considered repeal of matters that impede shipping reform or are inconsistent with the concept of company employment. This review stage was completed in 1998 and resulted in the Navigation Amendment (Employment of Seafarers) Bill 1998, which was introduced into Parliament on 25 June 1998. The House of Representatives passed the Navigation Amendment (Employment of Seafarers) Bill 1998 but it was obstructed in the Senate.

The second stage focussed on the remaining parts of the legislation that restricts competition or trading opportunities, are anachronistic or redundant, or which impose costs or confer benefits on business. The report of the second stage, entitled Review of the Navigation Act 1912, was released in June 2000 and has been available on the Department of Transport and Regional Services website at http://www.dotars.gov.au/transinfra/navact_reference.htm. The report is the most recent review of the Navigation Act and provides much of the information sought including the timing and conduct of the review, industry consultation and recommendations.

The implementation of the recommendations is being considered in the context of the Government's legislative program, bearing in mind the experience of earlier attempts to amend aspects of the Navigation Act 1912 that would have modernised and simplified the regulatory framework for ship operations. In addition to the Navigation Amendment (Employment of Seafarers) Bill 1998 referred to above, the Maritime Legislation Amendment Bill 2000 which sought to revise the trading ship safety regulatory framework under the Navigation Act 1912 was also passed by the House of Representatives but obstructed in the Senate.

(2) There is no restriction on supplementing the basic package of goods with other items, such as lounge furniture, wardrobes and chests of drawers but this is largely dependent on the availability of donated goods.

(3) Yes, HFS service providers are funded a set sum per family to provide household items, which is indexed annually for CPI increases. In 2002-03 this amount is $1200 per family. It was based on providing a basic set of goods for an average family size of 3.5 persons. The intent of HFS is that service providers have flexibility within the available funds to tailor a package for a family, and it is open to service providers to adjust the amounts provided to individual families although in practice needs are such that most receive the standard package.

(4) Yes, HFS service providers have expressed concerns regarding the limited amount of funding in the context of the IHSS Evaluation and in comments to the Review of Settlement Services. A response will be considered in the light of the Report on the Settlement Services Review.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts, upon notice, on 3 March 2003:

question.para: (1) Was there a failure of telecommunications services in Omeo on Saturday, 25 January 2003.
(2) Are telecommunications to Omeo provided through two switching centres at Wangaratta and Morwell.
(3) Was there an optic fibre failure from Wangaratta and a mains power failure to Morwell and the Morwell telephone exchange which led to the isolation of Omeo and surrounding areas.
(4) Was backup power provided at the Morwell exchange through local power generation equipment, and was the capacity of the equipment adequate to cover the mains power failure.
(5) What arrangements have been put in place to prevent such a serious failure happening again.
(6) Was the telecommunications failure at Morwell similar to previous mains power cuts at Pakenham and Kyneton telephone exchanges which also led to major telecommunications outages.
(7) What arrangements are in place to monitor such failures.

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question based on information provided by Telstra:

answer.para: (1) Yes. A telephone exchange failure affected fixed services connected to the Omeo Telephone Exchange for a period of 102 minutes - Telstra CDMA mobile phone services at Omeo were not affected by this outage.
This Outage was as a result of two isolated and unusually rare coincidental elements.

On the 25th of Jan 2003 at 4:47pm a transmission failure occurred between Bright and Hotham Heights. This was caused by the underground optical fibre cable between Bright and Mt Hotham being damaged by fire emergency services crews constructing a fire break for the bush fires in that area. This outage had no effect on telephone services in Omeo at this time. The Mt Hotham area was declared an unsafe and hazardous area and Telstra staff were delayed for several days in entering the area to repair the damaged optical fibre cable.

On Saturday the 25th of January a grass fire at Morwell caused a general mains power failure which resulted in loss of mains power to the Morwell telephone exchange. The Morwell exchange's emergency power generator would normally have started to operate. However, the generator failed due to overload when both the exchange rectifiers and the air conditioning unit attempted to start up at the same time. The loss of transmission to Omeo was caused by the subsequent air conditioning unit failure at Morwell.

(2) Yes, communications to Omeo are protected by two transmission paths; Morwell to Omeo via Wangaratta and Mt Hotham, and Morwell to Omeo via Bairnsdale. With the damage to the optical fibre cable caused by the bushfires at Mount Hotham, Omeo still had service via a backup transmission path to the telephone switch at Morwell via Bairnsdale. However, the backup transmission path was lost when the air conditioning unit at Morwell subsequently failed.

If not for the day's earlier fire damage and the compounding effects of the Morwell air conditioning failure, service would have remained uninterrupted to Omeo because traffic would have been able to travel along one of two routes: Morwell to Omeo via Wangaratta and Mt Hotham, and Morwell to Omeo via Bairnsdale.

(3) Yes, there was optic fibre failure resulting in fixed line services through Omeo being affected. However, Telstra's CDMA mobile phone service allowed mobile communications to the Omeo area to continue during the outage.

(4) Under normal circumstances, the emergency power plant at Morwell is adequate for the purpose. However, the extreme weather conditions on the 25th January (some 45 Degrees Celcius) meant that when the generator at the Morwell exchange started up, the load on it from the rectifiers and the air conditioning unit at start-up was too great, resulting in the failure of the generator and the air conditioning unit.

(5) The cutting of the optical fibre cable at Mt Hotham was beyond the control of Telstra. Telstra has already modified power equipment and the air conditioning unit at the Morwell exchange to ensure that the power overload condition does not arise in the future.
(6) No. All failures were based on different causes.

(7) The Telstra Global Operations Centre continuously monitors Telstra's network, immediately following up any network and/or power alarms. Additionally, routine maintenance programs and load testing are undertaken on all mains power back-up systems. Such testing is undertaken under normal load conditions -it is extremely difficult to simulate the heat conditions experienced on the 25th January.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs, upon notice, on 3 March 2003:

question.para: (1) Since the Government's election in 1996 to the present day, how many visas has he personally cancelled.
(2) Will he provide a time line for cancellations.
(3) In each case, what type of visa was held.
(4) On what grounds was each visa cancelled.
(5) Why were the visas cancelled by him rather than a delegate, thus ruling out any right of administrative review.
(6) What are the guidelines for the cancellation of a visa by the Minister, as opposed to a delegate.

(7) Can he provide details of any changes since the introduction of the scheme for visa cancellation on character grounds centred on s.501 of the Migration Act in relation to (a) the proportion of cancellation decisions made by the Minister personally, rather than by delegates and (b) the policies or guidelines applying to the question of whether and when such decisions are to be made by the Minister personally, rather than by delegates.

(8) In relation to the introduction of any such changes, what consideration was given to the fact that a person whose visa is cancelled in this way by the Minister personally has no right of independent review by the Administrative Appeals Tribunal (AAT), whereas there is such a right of review when the decision is made by a delegate.
(9) Was one of the reasons for the introduction of any such change a desire to remove the right of independent review in the AAT.

talker.name: Ruddock, Philip, MP
Mr Ruddock
talker.role: Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Reconciliation

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) There are a number of powers in the Migration Act 1958 that I can utilise to cancel a visa. These are:
section 109 incorrect information
section 116 general power to cancel
section 128 when holder outside Australia
section 134 cancellation of business visas
section 137Q cancellation of regional sponsored employment visas
section 140 consequential cancellation of other visas
section 500A refusal or cancellation of temporary safe haven visas
section 501 refusal or cancellation of visa on character grounds
section 501A or 501B refusal or cancellation of visa - setting aside and substitution of non-adverse decision under subsection 501 (1) or (2)

Since 1 June 1999, section 501 has predominantly replaced criminal deportation as the method used to ensure the safety and welfare of the Australian community. Previously, section 200 had been used for this purpose.

The vast majority of decisions made under these powers are decided by Department officers acting as my delegates. Decisions I have taken personally to cancel a visa are predominantly related to character concerns, often involving significant criminal activity. Based on the records available to the Department some 58,200 visas have been cancelled since 1996-97, of which I have personally cancelled approximately 570 visas.

(2) The time line for any case where possible visa cancellation is to be considered can vary significantly depending on a range of elements relevant to the case in question. Such elements may include the particular circumstances of the case, whether further information may be required to reach a decision, including information from other agencies, where appropriate, submissions from the person concerned regarding the proposed cancellation and whether there are international obligations that need to be taken into account. These processes are an important step in ensuring that all relevant material pertaining to a decision, and my responsibility to protect the Australian community, are given proper consideration against the relevant legislation before a decision is made.
(3) The Department does not keep statistics on the specific type of visa cancelled by me, although most would be permanent residents who had criminal records.

(4) The Department does not keep statistical data on the “grounds” for section 501 cancellations in individual cases. The Migration Act sets out the possible grounds for cancellation decisions where the person does not pass the “character test”.

(5) The Government is most concerned at the presence in Australia of non-citizens convicted of serious crimes and believes the Australian community is entitled to be protected against them. Generally, I decide cases personally under section 501 of the Migration Act if a visa holder (normally a permanent visa holder) is to be considered for cancellation as a result of serious character concerns regarding the visa holder. I may also set aside a non-adverse decision whether it has been considered by a delegate or the Administrative Appeals Tribunal (AAT) under section 501A, if the person does not satisfy me that they pass the “character test” and I am satisfied the cancellation is in the national interest.

(6) Guidelines to consider possible visa cancellation are provided to my delegates in Migration Serial Instructions (MSIs) 133, 254, 335 and 368. Direction No. 21 made under s499 of the Migration Act (“Visa refusal and cancellation under section 501”) provides further instruction for delegates. While I may be informed by these guidelines I have discretion to consider each case on its own merits.

(7) (a) Visa cancellations on character grounds centred on s501 of the Migration Act predominantly replaced criminal deportation under s200 from 1 June 1999. The proportion of cancellation decisions made by the Minister personally is given in the table below:
The proportion of cancellation decisions made by the Minister personally:

(b) As I stated in my response to part (5), I generally decide cases personally under section 501 of the Migration Act if a visa holder (normally a permanent visa holder) is to be considered for cancellation as a result of serious character concerns. I may also set aside a non-adverse decision by a delegate or the AAT under section 501A if the person does not satisfy me that they pass the “character test” and I am satisfied that it is in the national interest to cancel that person's visa.

(8) and (9) The powers I have under s501 and s501A of the Migration Act were approved by Parliament. As I informed the Parliament in my Second Reading Speech for the Migration Legislation Amendment (Strengthening of Provisions relating to Character and Conduct) Bill 1998, these powers are used when it is necessary for me “to act decisively on matters of visa cancellation ... to ensure that the government can effectively discharge its fundamental responsibility to prevent the entry and stay in Australia of non-citizens who have a criminal background or have criminal associations”.

subdebateinfo.title: Rural and Regional Australia: Flood Mitigation Program
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 1544)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Regional Services, Territories and Local Government, upon notice, on 3 March 2003:

question.para: (1) Has the Federal Government provided funding for flood mitigation works in Fairfield City, NSW.
(2) In what year was the funding discontinued.
(3) For what reason was funding discontinued.
(4) What sums does the government expend on the Regional Flood Mitigation Program.

(5) Does the Regional Flood Mitigation Program allow for funding for works in outer metropolitan areas; if so, (a) what outer metropolitan areas have received funding under the program and (b) why is Fairfield City not included in the definition of outer metropolitan.

talker.name: Tuckey, Wilson, MP
Mr Tuckey
talker.role: Minister for Regional Services, Territories and Local Government

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) Yes.
(3) The Federal Government ceased to provide assistance for urban flood mitigation funding in 1996-1997 in line with the recommendation of the 1996 National Commission of Audit Report.

(4) Since the RFMP was established in 1999-2000, the Federal Government has allocated $30.35 million to flood mitigation works and measures across Australia. A further $9.6 million will be allocated nationally in both 2003-2004 and 2004-2005.

Wentworthville (Parramatta City Council);
Baulkham Hills (Baulkham Hills Shire Council);
Camden (Camden Council)
(b) The inclusion or exclusion of Fairfield City under the RFMP is a matter for the NSW State Government.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, upon notice, on 4 March 2003:

question.para: (1) Who is eligible for inclusion in the Nominal Roll of Vietnam Veterans and what period does the Nominal Roll cover.

(2) Are there any Australian Defence Force personnel who served in the Active War Zone of South Vietnam, not prior to, but after, the Paris Agreement was signed on 27 January 1973, included in the Nominal Roll.

talker.name: Vale, Danna, MP
Mrs Vale
talker.role: Minister for Veterans' Affairs and Minister Assisting the Minister for Defence

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) The Nominal Roll of Vietnam Veterans currently includes all members of the Australian Defence Force who landed in Vietnam or entered Vietnamese waters during the period between 23 May 1962 and 1 July 1973. Civilians listed include merchant seamen who sailed on ships chartered by the Government for transport duties to Vietnam, medical and surgical teams provided under SEATO auspices, Australian Forces Overseas Fund members, official entertainers, war correspondents, Foreign Affairs personnel and QANTAS aircrew, and those who had been awarded or were eligible to receive the Vietnam Logistics Service Medal.
The period 23 May 1962 to 1 July 1973 was selected to cover the period between the announcement of Australian involvement in 1962 at the withdrawal of the Embassy Guard Platoon, Saigon in 1973.

(2) Members of the Embassy Guard Platoon, Saigon (whose service in South Vietnam began before but continued after the signing of the Paris Agreement on 27 January 1973) are included in the nominal roll.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 6 March 2003:

question.para: (1) Further to his Press Release of 19 December 2002 announcing the formation of the Special Operations Command, will the full component of 310 highly trained soldiers referred to only be provided in 2006.
(2) As soldiers are selected for the Special Operations Command, will the resultant vacancies be back filled or will the unit be left hollow.
(3) How many positions will be involved in the Special Combat Service Team and when will it be fully operational.
(4) In relation to the Special Operations Command; for each rank, how many (a) existing positions and (b) new positions will be involved and over what time period will they be filled.

talker.name: Vale, Danna, MP
Mrs Vale
talker.role: Minister for Veterans' Affairs and Minister Assisting the Minister for Defence

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

answer.para: (1) No. The Army will progressively transfer and recruit soldiers into Special Operations Command after its formal establishment on 1 May 2003.

(2) Army will progressively fill all vacancies within the Special Operations Command from May 2003 to January 2006 and will back fill positions left vacant as soldiers transfer from conventional units to Special Operations Command. The Army is considering direct recruiting to Special Operations Command to reduce the impact on units outside Special Operations Command.

(3) The Special Operations Combat Service Support Company is a sub-unit sized organisation. The specific numbers cannot be released for security reasons. The Special Operations Combat Service Support Company will be operational by 2006.

(4) The detailed numbers and growth plan for the Special Operations Command are classified. It is expected that the Special Operations Command will grow from approximately 1800 to approximately 2500 all ranks by January 2006. These figures include the staff for the Headquarters and all the units of the Command.

(5) Details of the equipment being provided to the additional Commando Company and to the new Combat Service Support Company cannot be released for security reasons. The cost of the equipment will be announced at the Budget.

(6) Have those same patients been advised by the Minister's department, or any other Commonwealth agency, about the potentially adverse effects of Myodil; if not, why not.
(7) How many patients who were prescribed iophendylate subsequently developed Adhesive Arachnoiditis.
(8) Is there a known cure or treatment for Adhesive Arachnoiditis.
(9) Have any studies been undertaken in Australia into the number of Adhesive Arachnoiditis sufferers; if so, what are the details.
(10) Has the Minister's Department, or any other Commonwealth agency, sponsored research into the after effects of the use of Myodil.
(11) Has the Minister's Department, or any other Commonwealth agency, provided financial support for Adhesive Arachnoiditis support groups.

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Health and Ageing has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

answer.para: (1) Myodil and Pantopaque imaging dyes were available in Australia from at least the early 1960s until the late 1980s. They were thus available before the introduction of Commonwealth regulation of medicines and therapeutic products in 1970. At the time of their use, they were the best method available to help diagnose serious spinal conditions, including disc diseases and tumours. No other form of contrast dye was available for myelography until the late 1970s.

In the late 1970s, the Therapeutic Goods Administration's predecessor, the Therapeutic Goods Branch of the then Department of Health, evaluated an application to register Pantopaque, for general marketing in Australia. This application was approved in October 1979.

(2) Myodil and Pantopaque were removed from the market in the late 1980s by their sponsors due to a lack of demand, as newer diagnostic techniques, such as Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI) and Computerised Topography (CT) scans, became available.

(3) Like many drugs, iophendylate contains a benzene unit within its chemical structure, but does not contain the compound benzene itself. It does contain 30.5% of organically bound iodine, but this, again, is part of the molecule itself and free iodine is unlikely to be released. There is no evidence that Myodil contains hydrochloric acid, sulphuric acid or potassium permanganate. However, some of these chemicals may have been used during the manufacture of iophendylate.

(4) (a) Yes, benzene is a known carcinogen; (b) potassium permanganate is harmful if swallowed; and (c) the Department can locate no scientific evidence indicating that incorrect use of iodine can lead to Parkinson's disease.

(5) No. At the time these dyes were first used, there was no Commonwealth regulation of therapeutic goods. Subsequently, regulation focussed on supply was introduced. As with any other product available on the market, the Commonwealth would not keep or have access to details of use in individual patients.

(6) No, but these products could only be given on the prescription of a doctor. The prescribing information for health professionals for Myodil from the early 1970s, and for Pantopaque when it was granted marketing approval, stated that the product should be removed after the myelographic procedure, and warned about the possibility of arachnoiditis and other adverse effects. Information on possible adverse effects was also documented in the scientific literature.

(7) It is not known how many sufferers of Adhesive Arachnoiditis are in Australia or what proportion of these had been treated with iophendylate prior to the development of this condition. However, it has variously been reported in the published scientific papers that clinically significant Arachnoiditis occurs in around 1% of patients who have undergone myelography with such dyes.
(8) The Department is not aware of a known cure or treatment for Adhesive Arachnoiditis.
(9) The Department is not aware of any Australian studies into the number of sufferers of Adhesive Arachnoiditis.
(10) The Department of Health and Ageing has not sponsored research into the after effects of the use of Myodil. I cannot comment on whether other Commonwealth agencies have sponsored such research.

(11) The Department of Health and Ageing has not provided financial support for Adhesive Arachnoiditis support groups. I cannot comment on whether other Commonwealth agencies have provided financial support.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts, upon notice, on 18 March 2003:

question.para: (1) Is it the case that the Telstra subsidiary, Sensis, replaced retrenched Sensis staff with outsourced staff from Stellar Call Centres Pty Ltd, a joint venture between Telstra and Excell Asia Pacific Pty Ltd; if so, how many Sensis staff were retrenched and how many Stellar Call Centres Pty Ltd staff were rehired on an outsourced basis.

(6) What is the nature and purpose of Telstra's investment in Stellar Call Centres Pty Ltd.

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts has provided the following answer, based on information provided by Telstra, to the honourable member's question:

answer.para: (1) No, retrenched Sensis staff were not replaced by Stellar Call Centres Pty Ltd staff.
Furthermore, no permanent staff were retrenched from Sensis and re-hired through Stellar Call Centres Pty Ltd (`Stellar').
(2) Sensis has two contracts with Stellar for the provision of services.

Stellar is providing Sensis with a call centre to answer Yellow Pages Connect calls. Sensis operates the Yellow Pages Connect service; which is a premium, advertiser referral service. Details regarding payments by Sensis to Stellar under this contract are commercial-in-confidence.

Stellar also provides data entry and call centre services. These services consist of providing timely and accurate maintenance of customer information and directory listings within the Sensis and Telstra databases. Details regarding payments by Sensis to Stellar under this contract are commercial-in-confidence.
Both of these contracts were rolled over into an umbrella agreement effective from 1 January 2003.
(3) Details regarding payments by Sensis to Stellar are commercial-in-confidence.
(4) Sensis board member and Stellar board member, Mr Andrew Day, receives no payment or benefit from Stellar Call Centres Pty Ltd.
Mr Day's travel costs to attend Stellar Board meetings are paid for by Telstra.
(5) For the Yellow Pages Connect service, Stellar was the only organisation, at the time, with the technological capability suitable to support the Yellow Pages Connect platform.

For the customer operations service in May 2002, Teletech, United Customer Management Solutions and Stellar were invited to respond to a brief detailing Sensis' requirements for services. Of the three responses received, the Stellar quote was the lowest cost and most suitable.
(6) The nature of Telstra's investment in Stellar Call Centres Pty Ltd is as follows:
Stellar is an incorporated joint venture owned 50% by Telstra and 50% by US call centre specialists, Excell Global Services LLC (`Excell').
Pursuant to the Stellar shareholders agreement, both Telstra and Excell are entitled to appoint three directors.
The right to appoint the Chairman is shared between both parties on a rotational basis.
In making the decision to invest in Stellar, Telstra's purpose was to strategically position itself in the expanding call centre market.

subdebateinfo.title: Foreign Affairs: Democratic People's Republic of Korea
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 1701)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 17 March 2003:

quote.para: (1) Can he provide details of the occasions since March 1996 when he has described the Democratic People's Republic of Korea (DPRK) as a threat to Australia's security.

(2) Can he provide details of the Governments assessment of: (a) the number of (i) nuclear weapons warheads, (ii) chemical weapons warheads and (iii) biological weapons warheads, and (b) the number of missiles including: (i) the type, and (ii) their range, in the DPRK's possession.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: (1) I have on many occasions referred to the DPRK as a threat to Australia's security. Recent instances include:

- on 10 March 2003 I wrote in the International Herald Tribune, `... any move by the North to reprocess its spent reactor fuel rods to extract plutonium', or `... launching a long-range ballistic missile...' `... would destabilise the region and have global ramifications.'
- on 2 March 2003, on Channel 10's Meet the Press I said `(Iraq and DPRK)...are both very substantial threats to international security and that includes Australia.'
- on 28 February 2003, in an interview with Tricia Duffield on radio 2SM, I said the DPRK `is quite a threat.'

- on 27 February 2003, in a doorstop interview, I said `if North Korea is going to continue to develop its nuclear program and... missile systems... that's a major security threat to the Asia-Pacific Region as well as the world beyond.'
- on 12 February 2003 during Question Time in the House of Representatives, I said `We do see it (the DPRK) as a serious threat to regional security.'

- on 3 January 2003, in The Age I wrote `The ramifications of an overt and expanding nuclear weapons program in North Korea would be disastrous for the Asia-Pacific region and beyond ... The region would be destabilised and global resources would be diverted.'

- on 11 March 2003, the Joint Ministerial Statement of the Sixth Australia-Indonesia Ministerial Forum `expressed serious concern at the threat to regional and global security posed by the DPRK's nuclear program.'

(2) (a) (i) While it is difficult to be certain that North Korea actually has nuclear weapons the Government's assessment is that it could have enough weapons-grade fissile material for one or two, or possibly three nuclear weapons; (ii) & (iii) North Korea is thought to be developing or already has chemical and biological weapons but there is no detailed information available on actual DPRK holdings of these weapons.

(b) North Korea is thought to have large numbers of Scud and No-Dong missiles. The Scuds have estimated ranges of 300-500 kms, while the No-Dong has a range of 1300 kms. North Korea also continues to develop an inter-continental ballistic missile (ICBM), the Taepo Dong-2. The range of the Taepo Dong-2 would depend on configuration and payload but could go as high as 15,000 kms. Operational deployment of the Taepo Dong-2 is probably still some years away.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 19 March 2003:

question.para: (1) Can he advise whether AusAID has had any contact with the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees (UNHCR) or other UN bodies on the matter of Iraqi refugees arising from a potential conflict with Iraq; if so, what are the details (dates, time, locations, and with whom) of those dealings.

(2) Can he advise whether AusAID has had any contact with UN organisations on the matter of post-war reconstruction efforts in Iraq; if so, what were those organisations, and what are the details (dates, time, locations, with whom and content) of that contact.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) Prior to the 19th March 2003, AusAID officials held a number of sessions with the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees (UNHCR), the International Organisation of Migration (IOM) and other United Nations representatives in Geneva, New York and Canberra. In addition, there was substantial e-mail, correspondence and general briefing sessions between AusAID officials and the various UN agencies.

(2) Prior to the 19th March 2003, AusAID officials had regular contact with various United Nations organisations including United Nations Development Program (UNDP); World Health Organisation (WHO); Organisation for Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs (OCHA) and the United Nations Children's Fund (UNICEF) on potential reconstruction priorities and activities in Iraq. These meetings were held primarily in Geneva, New York and Canberra. AusAID contact with these organisations was primarily the provision of general briefing information of a regional and country specific nature, organisation preparedness planning and the potential mobilisation of Australian aid personnel to post-war Iraq.

(4) The allocation of aged care places is governed by the Aged Care Act 1997 (the Act), which contains provisions relating to the transfer of aged care places from one provider to another and the variation of conditions of allocation of places, e.g. from one locality to another. If a provider wishes to vary the location at which aged care places are available, the provider must apply to the Department of Health and Ageing for approval to do so. Each application is considered in accordance with criteria specified in the Act and in the Allocations Principles 1997. For variations of the conditions of allocation, in deciding whether the variation is justified in the circumstances, the Department must consider whether the variation would meet the objectives of the aged care planning process specified in the Act.

(5) Yes; representations have been received from both the Member for Gippsland and the Member for Macmillan. The Members were advised that if the Approved Provider wished to seek capital funding it would need to apply to the Department of Health and Ageing through the annual Aged Care Approvals Round.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Regional Services, Territories and Local Government, upon notice, on 24 March 2003:

(2) Is the Government aware that the Fairfield City Council has identified 330 houses that require raising.

(3) Is the Government aware that the Fairfield City Council has identified 93 houses for voluntary purchase, of which 73 have been purchased and will the Government make enquiries about the purchase of the remaining 20.
(4) Has the Government received requests from the Fairfield City Council for flood mitigation funding since 2000; if so, how many and what was the Governments response to each request.
(5) Is the Government willing to reassess the costs of flooding in metropolitan areas; if so, will the Government attempt to re-establish a metropolitan flood mitigation scheme; if not, why not.

talker.name: Tuckey, Wilson, MP
Mr Tuckey
talker.role: Minister for Regional Services, Territories and Local Government

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) I am advised that Parramatta City Council is one of several NSW local councils to share in a statewide voluntary purchase allocation of $950,000 in Federal Government funds in 2002-2003. This funding is not for the sole benefit of Parramatta City Council, and the final amount to be allocated to the Council is yet to be finalised by the NSW State Government.

(2) and (3) While the Federal Government does not have an in-depth knowledge of the current status of Fairfield City Council's house raising and voluntary purchase projects, it is aware of the overall magnitude of the flood problem facing Council. Flood mitigation, however, is essentially a State Government responsibility and the priority to be given to the purchase of the remaining 20 houses in Fairfield is a matter for Council to address with the NSW State Government.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs, upon notice, on 24 March 2003:

question.para: (1) In respect of this announcement on 19 March 2003 that the temporary immigration detention centre on Christmas Island has been mothballed, why were the three people transferred to Nauru and not to an Australian immigration detention centre.

(2) In respect of the three people transferred to Nauru: (a) when did they first arrive at Christmas Island, (b) what are their nationalities, (c) to which camp on Nauru have they been transferred, (d) what was the status of their applications for refugee status at the time they were transferred, and (e) who will be conducting the remainder of the assessments of their refugee status.

talker.name: Ruddock, Philip, MP
Mr Ruddock
talker.role: Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Reconciliation

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) Under s198A of the Migration Act the people in question are offshore entry persons who entered Australia at Christmas Island, an excised offshore place after the excision time for that place and became unlawful non-citizens because of their entry. As Offshore Entry Persons they were transferred to Nauru as they had declined the Afghan reintegration package or were waiting for removal to their country of origin.
Nauru was declared on 2 October 2001 under the requirements of s198A (3) of the Act.

(2) (a) The three detainees arrived on separate boats at various locations. The first detainee arrived at Christmas Island on 30 October 2001, the second detainee arrived 14 November 2001 and the third on 28 May 2002.
(b) Two claim to be Afghan nationals and the other claims to be a Bangladeshi national.
(c) The three detainees arrived in Nauru on Wednesday 19 March 2003 and entered the Topside Offshore Processing Centre.

(d) At the time of transfer to Nauru the two Afghan nationals had received Refugee Status Determination (RSD) both at primary and review stages and had been determined not to be refugees. The Bangladeshi national did not prima facie engage protection obligations. The RSD is a system developed for processing unauthorised arrivals seeking protection who are on an excised offshore place or in a declared country. The RSD is modelled on the refugee assessment processes of the UNHCR.

(e) As indicated above, all three detainees have been assessed as not engaging protection obligations or other international treaty obligations. No humanitarian considerations were presented by these people. The three people are awaiting removal or repatriation as soon as circumstances permit.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: (1) If a serviceperson is injured, develops an illness or dies as a consequence of defence service, the Military Compensation Scheme provides benefits under the Safety, Rehabilitation and Compensation Act 1988 (SRCA). Additionally, where the claim arises from a period of operational service, compensation and health care may be provided under the Veterans' Entitlements Act 1986 (VEA). In the latter case, offsetting provisions apply so that the same injury / incapacity is not compensated twice. Under the Defence Act 1903 additional amounts of compensation is payable to those who are severely injured, or to the families of those who die, in compensable circumstances.
(2) All Australian Defence Force personnel allotted for service with Operation Falconer who serve in the operational area will be eligible for the full range of benefits.
(3) No, the future cost is dependent on the rate of claims which may arise from service in Operation Falconer.

Mrs Vale

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs, upon notice, on 24 March 2003:

quote.para: (1) Further to his answer to question No. 957 (Hansard, 11 November 2002, page 8755) has he considered implementing a nation-wide protocol for all immigration detention centres in relation to the request for sanitary products and their distribution to female detainees.
(2) Will he consider expanding the conditions relating to the provision of sanitary products to female detainees as in the Baxter detention centre, to all other detention centres.

talker.name: Ruddock, Philip, MP
Mr Ruddock
talker.role: Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Reconciliation

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: (1) Under the Immigration Detention Standards, Australasian Correctional Management (ACM) is required to operate in a manner that preserves the dignity and privacy of all detainees including females. Request and distribution arrangements for sanitary products are therefore established to ensure that female detainees can be provided with their sanitary products in the most discreet manner possible.

Each Immigration Detention Facility has individual arrangements in place for the distribution of sanitary products to female immigration detainees. These arrangements are tailored to meet the needs of female detainees at each centre and the arrangements take into account the physical layout (infrastructure) of each centre, the composition of ACM staff (availability of female ACM officers) and the profile of the detainee population. It is for this reason that implementing a nation-wide protocol for all immigration detention centres in relation to the request for sanitary products and their distribution to female detainees would likely prove difficult.
(2) The conditions relating to the provision of sanitary products to female detainees in the Baxter detention centre when compared to all other detention centres, are similar.

In some of the other centres (see below), such as Christmas Island Immigration Reception and Processing Centre, and the Maribyrnong and Perth Immigration Detention Centres, there are no restrictions on the supply of sanitary products or on the number of requests.

Any differences between the arrangements operating at each centre are due to the physical layout (infrastructure) of each centre, the composition of ACM staff (availability of female ACM officers) and the profile of the detainee population. It is for these reasons that expanding the conditions relating to the provision of sanitary products to female detainees in the Baxter detention centre, to all other centres, may not be practicable.
The individual arrangements operating at each centre are as follows:

answer.para: Baxter Immigration Detention Facility

quote.para: Upon verbal request to a female ACM officer or female nursing staff member all female detainees are provided with sanitary napkins from a female ACM officer or female nursing staff member. ACM has advised that tampons are provided on request. However, tampons are not generally a popular product among the female detainee population.
Female detainees are given a three months supply of sanitary products at the time of each request.
They may seek further supplies when they foresee that their three months supply will run out.
Sanitary products may be obtained from the nurse who is located at the nurses' station in their compound.
Sanitary products are supplied in discreet bags.

answer.para: Perth Immigration Detention Centre

quote.para: Various sanitary products are available to all female detainees.
There is no restriction on the supply of sanitary products.
There is no restriction on the number of requests.
Sanitary products are supplied by the nurse. ACM officers are not involved.

answer.para: Port Hedland Immigration Reception and Processing Centre

quote.para: Female detainees are able to access sanitary products by requesting the products from ACM Welfare Officers. Sanitary pads are supplied by ACM to female detainees, or they may purchase tampons from the shop if they wish.
Once a request has been made, a female detainee is provided with one packet of sanitary pads.
Detainees may submit requests as often as necessary.
Female detainees submit a request to an ACM Welfare Officer in order to obtain sanitary pads.
Female detainees can collect sanitary pads from the ACM Welfare Officer on Mondays, Wednesdays and Fridays.

answer.para: Woomera Immigration Reception and Processing Centre

quote.para: Sanitary products are available in each compound from the ACM administration office block which houses provisions for the detainees. There is always at least one female ACM officer on duty.
There is no limit placed on the number of pads or tampons available for distribution.
Female detainees may request sanitary products as often as necessary.
Female detainees may request sanitary products from a female ACM officer in the compound, as there is always at least one female officer on duty.
Sanitary products are issued in packages that are discreetly wrapped.

answer.para: Woomera Residential Housing Project

quote.para: Women go to the main office at the RHP and request pads.
Pads are freely issued by the women detention officers. Products are issued discreetly.
Sanitary napkins are provided as tampons are not popular with the female detainees.
Women are provided with an unopened pack of pads when requested.

answer.para: Christmas Island Immigration Reception and Processing Centre

quote.para: Sanitary products are stored at the ACM officer post in Charlie block dormitory. A small supply of sanitary products is also stored in the medical clinic.

Upon request to a female ACM officer or female nursing staff member, a female detainee is provided with sufficient products to last five to six days. Most requests are for sanitary napkins, not tampons.
There is no restriction on the number of requests made.
Female detainees may either speak to medical staff, or to an ACM female officer, or they may request the products in writing.
Either medical staff or female ACM officers provide the sanitary products to the detainees.

answer.para: Villawood Immigration Detention Centre

quote.para: As the majority of female detainees are housed in LIMA compound, which is fully staffed by ACM female officers, sanitary products are stored in the compound.
Sanitary pads are issued five or six at a time (the female detainees have indicated that this is their preference), while tampons are provided in sealed packs of ten.
Sanitary products are provided when required and on request.
Female detainees, including those in the general compound, verbally request sanitary products from a female ACM LIMA compound staff officer.
Pads are issued in discreet bags, while the tampon packs are small enough to be placed in a pocket or small bag.

answer.para: Maribyrnong Immigration Detention Centre

quote.para: Sanitary products are available from the ACM female dormitory officer.
There is no restriction on the supply of sanitary products.
There is no restriction on the number of requests.
Female detainees can request sanitary products from the ACM female dormitory officer.
Sanitary products are delivered to the detainees by hand.
Products are also available in the kitchen.

answer.para: Curtin Immigration Reception and Processing Centre (now closed)

quote.para: Sanitary napkins were supplied upon request. Tampons were not popular with the female detainees.

Supply was consistent with detainees' monthly requirements, with a slight oversupply rather than undersupply of the products to the detainees occurring as a general rule, in order to ensure detainees' needs were fully met.
When required or anticipated to be required.
Female detainees would attend the welfare area where products were dispensed through the assistance of a female detainee who assisted ACM staff in the area.
Supplies were delivered in discreet bags.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

(2) There is a well-established principle of accepting by consensus any uncontested candidate from a regional group for a position to be held by that group. talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts, upon notice, on 25 March 2003:

quote.para: (1) Which of the following suburbs in the electoral division of Hasluck have: (a) total access, (b) partial access, or (c) no access at all to Telstra's Internet ADSL Broadband technology: Bellevue, Castle Glen, Caversham, Crestwood, Forest Lakes, Forrestfield, Gooseberry Hill, Gosnells, Guildford, Hazelmere, Helena Valley, High Wycombe, Huntingdale, Kalamunda, Kenwick, Koongamia, Lesmurdie, Maddington, Maida Vale, Martin, Middle Swan, Midland, Midvale, Orange Grove, South Guildford, Thornlie, Viveash, Walliston, Wattle Grove, West Swan and Woodbridge.

(2) In respect of each suburb which is currently unable to access Telstra's Internet broadband technology, is the Minister able to; (a) confirm whether or not this is due to existing pair gaining technology; if not, what is the reason for lack of access, and (b) say when they will be able to access Telstra's Internet ADSL broadband technology; if not, why not.
(3) Which exchanges within the electoral division of Hasluck are: (a) ADSL broadband enabled, and (b) not ADSL broadband enabled.
(4) How close to an ADSL enabled exchange must a customer be located to guarantee them access to ADSL broadband.
(5) Are there any other factors which affect ADSL broadband access other than excessive distance to an ADSL enabled exchange.

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question, based on advice provided by Telstra:

quote.para: (1) There are 17 exchanges, wholly or partly, within the electoral division of Hasluck and all of these exchanges are ADSL enabled. Therefore all of the suburbs identified in the question have access to ADSL. However, due to the impact of certain access line electronics and distance limit factors, access to ADSL is limited to approximately 86% of people with a telephone service within the Hasluck electorate.

(2) (a) As noted in the answer to part (1) above, approximately 14% of people within the Hasluck electorate are unable to access ADSL, due mainly to certain access line electronics and distance limit factors. (b) The access line electronics issue and distance factors mean that ADSL will never reach 100% of premises. Nevertheless, areas of high aggregate demand for broadband within the existing ADSL footprint may be retrofitted at some time in the future where this is considered economically viable. In this context, Telstra is currently developing an online Broadband Demand Register to assist in assessing broadband demand in particular areas.
Generally speaking, for customers unable to access ADSL, the current alternatives are:
satellite (available everywhere);
ISDN (available at virtually all urban exchanges); and
cable (which passes approximately one third of living units in Australia)
While households in the Hasluck electorate do not have access to cable infrastructure, the other two alternatives are available.

(3) There are 17 exchanges, wholly or partly, within the electoral division of Hasluck, of which all are already ADSL enabled. The Huntingdale exchange, adjacent to Hasluck, is planned to be enabled by the end of June 2003.

(4) A customer must be located within approximately 3.5 kms from their exchange in order to access ADSL. This approximate distance limit is driven by technical standards, and is determined in each case by the electrical attenuation of the copper telephone line. Each customer's line is checked for its capability to be provided with ADSL, before Telstra proceed with ADSL service provision.
(5) Apart from the exchange not being enabled, the main reasons for customers being unable to access ADSL are:
excessive distance from the exchange, and the presence of certain access line electronics.
There are also three further conditions that can infrequently occur, and will also prevent ADSL:
an incompatible product utilising the existing copper line (eg, ISDN);
a potentially interfering product utilising an adjacent copper pair in the cable; and
special line conditioning equipment on some cables required to improve voice transmission.
