Mr Ruddock
talker.role: Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Reconciliation

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) Under the Memorandum of Understanding on Consular Matters the Government of the Islamic Republic of Iran has agreed to accept the return of all Iranian nationals who have no legal right to remain in Australia, subject to their identity being confirmed.

(3) The Memorandum of Understanding on Consular Matters provides for the offer of financial assistance to promote and facilitate the voluntary return to Iran of Iranian nationals who have no legal right to remain in Australia. This reintegration package, which provides for AUD 2,000 per person and up to a maximum of AUD 10,000 per family, is designed to assist individuals and families to re-establish their lives in Iran. Officers of my Department will counsel detainees on the terms of the package. Iranian consular representatives will be available should detainees wish to discuss arrangements for their return to Iran.

(4) The Government does not consider it to be in the public interest to make the Memorandum of Understanding on Consular Matters publicly available at this time. The document was signed on the understanding that it is a confidential agreement between governments that would not be released publicly.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 27 March 2003:

question.para: (1) Further to his reply to question No. 1148 (Hansard, 12 December 2002, page 10631), is he aware of any allegations of human rights violations and property crime committed by Turkey against Australians of Cypriot origin.

(2) Will the Government provide any financial assistance to Australians of Cypriot origin in order for them to commence legal action against Turkey in the European Court of Human Rights (ECHR); if so, what will that assistance be; if not, why not.

(3) Will the Government support or sponsor the establishment of an Eminent Persons Group on Cyprus under the auspices of the Commonwealth Heads of Government (CHOGM); if so, is he able to say whom he will recommend for that group; if not, why not.
(4) Will the Government condemn Turkey for failing to comply with the ECHR judgement in both Loizidou vs. Turkey and Cyprus vs. Turkey; if so, when; if not, why not.
(5) What diplomatic pressure will the Government apply to persuade Turkey to comply with the judgements of the ECHR.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) I am aware that a number of dual Australian/Cypriot nationals have sought to take action against Turkey in the European Court of Human Rights over the denial of their property rights in northern Cyprus.

(2) Financial assistance under the Special Circumstances (Overseas) Scheme (which is the only scheme of possible relevance in this matter) is provided in only the most exceptional cases. Financial assistance may be authorised under that Scheme where there is a “moral obligation” on the part of the Commonwealth to provide assistance, or there are “compassionate grounds” for the Commonwealth to provide assistance. Assistance is usually provided only in relation to those matters where the Commonwealth has a direct involvement in the matter and the liberty of the person involved is at stake.

It is unlikely that this necessary element of `moral obligation' or `compassionate grounds' could be derived from private civil proceedings undertaken in a foreign country against a foreign government, on the basis of a foreign citizenship. This is particularly so because the Australian Government is, in principle, unconvinced of the merits of funding private legal actions against foreign governments in foreign courts.

(3) The Commonwealth has supported the resolution of the situation in Cyprus through encouragement of the multilateral mechanisms of the United Nations and through bilateral channels, rather than a parallel process of mediation. In the absence of any initiative by Cyprus, as the country most concerned, or by the Commonwealth Secretary-General, to establish an `eminent persons group' on Cyprus under the auspices of the Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting (CHOGM), Australia has not sponsored or supported the establishment of such a group.

(4) Australia is not a Party to the European Convention on Human Rights which established the European Court of Human Rights. It would therefore not be appropriate for Australia to comment on Turkey's compliance with the Court's judgements in Loizidou vs. Turkey and Cyprus vs. Turkey.

(5) Australia is not a Party to the European Convention on Human Rights which established the European Court of Human Rights. It would therefore not be appropriate for Australia to bring influence to bear on Turkey regarding its compliance with the Court's judgements.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Health and Ageing, upon notice, on 27 March 2003:

quote.para: (1) Further to the Minister's reply to part (6) of question No. 1170 (Hansard, 5 February 2003, page 11058), what evidence has been received by the Pharmaceutical Benefits Advisory Committee (PBAC) regarding the listing of Modafinil on the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme (PBS).
(2) Is the Minister able to say what evidence is required by the PBAC to enable a recommendation for PBS listing of Modafinil to be made; if so, what is the nature of that evidence; if not, why not.

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Health and Ageing has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

quote.para: (1) Applications made by sponsors to the Pharmaceutical Benefits Advisory Committee (PBAC) are commercial-in-confidence. As such, the Department is not in a position to provide these details.

(2) An application to the PBAC for listing a medicine on the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme (PBS) is required to include evidence relating to the medicine's clinical effectiveness, safety and cost-effectiveness compared with other treatments listed on the PBS.

talk.start.para: asked the Prime Minister, upon notice, on 27 March 2003:

question.para: (1) Does the Government have a policy on the circumstances in which it would be appropriate to translate Prime Ministerial and Ministerial statements into community languages at taxpayers' expense; if so, what are the details.
(2) What were the reasons behind the Government's decision to translate his parliamentary statement on Iraq into Arabic and Bahasa Indonesian and who initiated such action.
(3) Which Government agency arranged for the translations to be made and what was the cost.
(4) According to the 2001 Census, what proportion of Australians who speak a language other than English at home were recorded as speaking (a) Arabic and (b) Bahasa Indonesian.
(5) On what basis was it decided to translate the speech into these two particular languages and not into other languages.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) There is no set policy, but translations of Prime Ministerial and Ministerial statements are undertaken when there are compelling reasons on national and community interest grounds for broader community awareness of the content of such statements.

(2) The decision to translate the speech into Arabic reflected the fact that Iraq is an Arabic speaking country and many community groups with an interest in the Iraq issue are Arabic speakers. The translation into Indonesian reflected the fact that Indonesia has the world's largest Muslim population and is one of Australia's nearest neighbours. The action to arrange translation was initiated by my office.

(3) The Translation was arranged by the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet with the assistance of the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade. The cost of translation was approximately $176.
(4) (a) Arabic: 209,372 persons (1.1 per cent of the total Australian population)
(b) Indonesian: 38,724 persons (0.2 per cent of the total Australian population).
(5) As per (2) above.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 27 March 2003:

quote.para: (1) Further to his answer to question No. 1373 (Hansard, 25 March 2003, page 13246), is it the case that the US government supports the Iraqi National Congress and Kurdish autonomy as part of a federal Iraq; if so, is Australia's policy on Kurdish autonomy within a federal Iraq different to that of the Coalition of the Willing.
(2) Has the Australian government had a less supportive attitude to the Kurds than the British and the Americans; if so, why.
(3) Does the Government consider recognition of Kurdish authorities within the boundaries of Iraq to be equivalent to Australia supporting the creation of an independent Kurdish state; if so, why.
(4) Is the Australian government seeking to liberate the Iraqis, including the Iraqi Kurds; if so, why has it refused to meet or talk to them since 1993.

(5) When will he or his officials enter into discussions about the reconstruction of Iraq with the two Kurdish governments, whose freedom of speech, economic progress and relative freedom, he has been citing in the House.
(6) Was the US represented by Mr Ambassador Khalilzad at a meeting of all Iraqi exile groups in Sulaymaniyah in the Kurdish area of Iraq in February 2003.
(7) Did the Australian government seek or receive Mr Khalilzad's report on plans for a future democratic federal Iraq, if so, do these plans include an autonomous Iraqi Kurdistan.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: (1) It is not usually our practice to comment on the policy approach of other governments. Australia supports the cultural and political aspirations of ethnic groups in Iraq being met within existing territorial boundaries, and peacefully. Australia also supports genuine political representation and non-discriminatory policies for ethnic groups in Iraq. The Prime Minister, Mr Howard, has referred to possible application of the concept of federalism to post-conflict political arrangements in Iraq but has emphasised that the nature of Iraq's future government is ultimately a matter for the Iraqi people themselves to determine.

(3) The Australian Government does not recognise any of the Kurdish “Parliaments”, “Governments” or “Congresses” - whether located in Iraq or elsewhere - and does not accord their representatives any special status. For reasons relating to the territorial integrity of UN member states, Australia does not support the creation of an independent Kurdish state unless it is agreed to by all other states whose territorial integrity would be affected by the creation of such a state. Australia considers the Kurds to be minorities in the countries in which they live and believes that their cultural and political aspirations should be met by working within existing territorial boundaries. The Australian Government stresses the importance of fully respecting international human rights norms in the treatment of Kurdish minorities.

(4) The Government's key objective remains to disarm Iraq of its Weapons of Mass Destruction. Australian Government representatives continue to meet from time to time with Kurdish community leaders in Australia and overseas.

(5) See the response to Questions 3 and 4 above. Kurdish representatives attended the meeting held in Tallil, Iraq on 15 April to discuss future political arrangements in Iraq. Australia was represented at this meeting. Kurdish representatives must of course be involved in further discussions about the reconstruction of Iraq and transitional governance arrangements.
(6) This is an issue for the US Government.
